Unique quality assessment title (to be finalised by C3S), including [data stream]-[quality area]-for-[application area]#

This will be a short descriptive title, unique to each assessment and used in the links to this assessment.

This could be implemented programtically from defined lists of data_stream_tag, application_area_tag and quality_tag eventually.

Use case: Use case listed here in full#

Quality assessment question(s)#

  • In most cases there should be one question listed here in bold

  • In some cases a second question may be included

‘Context’ (no title/heading)- a very short introduction before the assessment statement describing approach taken to answer the user questions. One or two key references could be useful, especailly if the assessment summarises literature (referenced directly in the text, or with numerical labels like this: [1]).

Quality assessment statement#

Key results and guidance including an answer to the user question - to be visually highlighted and with the title ‘Quality assessment statement’.

  • Statement 1

  • Statement 2

  • Statement 3

  • etc

A ‘key figure’ could be included if appropriate (think of this as a ‘graphical abstract’, that may also be used as a thumbnail in the CDS or Jupyterbook). Since this image (or any other embedded image) is not generated directly from code, it needs to be saved externally and provided with the Notebook. There is an option for images to be dragged and dropped from an external file browser into the markdown cell (the image is then encoded with Base64, and no external file is needed - but this may not work universally or always render properly in a Jupyter Book - avoid this for now!).

Note: if the assessment does not include code (a literature review, paper or PQAR summary, etc), then this template can followed as a markdown (.md) rather than Notebook (.pynb) file. In this case attaching images to cells might work (without the local file).

Basic markdown test ![Test image](test_img.png) (but no formatting options, so the image must be the right size):

Simple alternative with html <img src="test_img.png" width="300px"> (width controlled via width=”300px” as needed):

Or centered if needed <img src="test_img.png" width="300px" style="display: block; margin: auto;">:

This MyST MD option allows a figure caption to be added, but will not render properly in all Jupyter viewers but works when the Jupyter book is built!

```{figure} test_img.png
---
height: 150px
name: example-fig
---
Here is my figure caption!
```

Which will render like:

Methodology#

A ‘free text’ introduction to the data analysis steps or a description of the literature synthesis, with a justification of the approach taken, and limitations mentioned.

Followed by a numbered list of the methodology and results, with the same headings as the sections under ‘Analysis and Results’. These should be links to the sections below using the format [Text to be displayed](#words-in-heading).

  • These headings can be specific to the quality assessment, and help guide the user through the ‘story’ of the assessment. This means we cannot pre-define the sections and headings here, as they will be different for each assessment.

  • Sub-bullets could be used to outline what will be done/shown/discussed in each section

E.g. ‘The analysis and results are organised in the following steps, which are detailed in the sections below:’

1. Section A E.g. ‘Choose the data to use and setup code’:

  • Sub-steps or key points listed in bullet below. No strict requirement to match and link to sub-headings.

2. Section B E.g. ‘Dataset 1 retrieval and area average’:

  • Sub-steps or key points listed in bullet below. No strict requirement to match and link to sub-headings.

3. Section C E.g. ‘Dataset 2 retrieval and area average’:

  • Sub-steps or key points listed in bullet below. No strict requirement to match and link to sub-headings.

4. Section D E.g. ‘Compute the bias’:

  • Sub-steps or key points listed in bullet below. No strict requirement to match and link to sub-headings.

5. Section E E.g. ‘Plot and describe results’:

  • Sub-steps or key points listed in bullet below. No strict requirement to match and link to sub-headings.

Any further notes on the method could go here.

Analysis and results#

Section A#

Subsections#

Describe what is done in this step/section and what the code in the cell does (if code is included - some assessment may review literature or reports like PQARs for ECVs). The code should be collapsed by default using the cell tag 'hide-input' (BOpen can check this programatically, and possibly update the cell tags automatically?). Cell output should be cleaned up as needed, this can also be done with the 'hide-output' cell tag.

Please link to any non-standard libraries in the text when they are imported, including the functions from BOpen (a standard line on this is also inluded in the references section).

Show code cell source Hide code cell source 
# collapsable code cells - use cell tag 'hide-input' for all cells, added via the cell settings or 'cogs' icon on the right

# code is included for transparency but also learning purposes and gives users the chance to adapt the code used for the assesment as they wish

Subsections#

Describe what is done in this step/section and what the code in the cell does (if code is included).

# collapsable code cells

# code is included for transparency but also learning purposes and gives users the chance to adapt the code used for the assesment as they wish

Subsections#

Section D#

Subsections#

Describe what is done in this step/section and what the code in the cell does(if code is included).

Section E#

Results Subsections#

Describe what is done in this step/section and what the code in the cell does (if code is included). If this is the results section, we expect the final plots to be created here with a description of how to interpret them, and what information can be extracted for the specific case shown. The information in the ‘quality assessment statement’ should be derived here.

If you want to know more#

Key resources#

List some key resources related to this assessment. E.g. CDS entries, applications, dataset documentation, external pages.

Code libraries used:

  • C3S EQC custom functions, c3s_eqc_automatic_quality_control, prepared by BOpen

References#

List the references used in the Notebook here.

E.g.

[1] Rodriguez, D., De Voil, P., Hudson, D., Brown, J. N., Hayman, P., Marrou, H., & Meinke, H. (2018). Predicting optimum crop designs using crop models and seasonal climate forecasts. Scientific reports, 8(1), 2231.
